description: From Middle English pole, pal, from Old English pāl (“a pole, stake, post; a kind of hoe or spade”), from Proto-West Germanic *pāl (“pole”), from Latin pālus (“stake, pale, prop, stay”), perhaps from Old Latin *paxlos, from Proto-Italic *pākslos, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *peh₂ǵ- (“to nail, fasten”). Doublet of peel, pale, and palus.

entries.meaning: Originally, a stick; now specifically, a long and slender piece of metal or (especially) wood, used for various construction or support purposes.
A construction by which an animal is harnessed to a carriage.
examples: Meronyms: pole-guard, pole-hook, pole-hound, pole-pad, pole-pin, pole-pin-strap, pole-plate, pole-ring, pole-screen, pole-socket, pole-stop, pole-strap
Synonyms: carriage pole, beam, shaft, drawbar

entries.meaning: (fishing) A type of basic fishing rod.
A long sports implement used for pole-vaulting; now made of glassfiber or carbon fiber, formerly also metal, bamboo and wood have been used.
(slang, spotting) A telescope used to identify birds, aeroplanes or wildlife.
(historical) A unit of length, equal to a rod (1⁄4 chain or 5+1⁄2 yards).
(motor racing) Pole position.
(US, African-American Vernacular, slang) A gun.
(vulgar, slang) A penis.

verbs.description: pole (third-person singular simple present poles, present participle poling, simple past and past participle poled)

entries.meaning: To propel by pushing with poles, to push with a pole.
examples: Huck Finn poled that raft southward down the Mississippi because going northward against the current was too much work.

entries.meaning: To identify something quite precisely using a telescope.
examples: He poled off the serial of the Gulfstream to confirm its identity.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To furnish with poles for support.
(transitive) To convey on poles.
examples: to pole hay into a barn

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stir, as molten glass, with a pole.
(transitive, baseball) To strike (the ball) very hard.

description: From Middle French pole, pôle, from Latin polus, from Ancient Greek πόλος (pólos, “axis of rotation”).

entries.meaning: Either of the two points on the earth's surface around which it rotates; also, similar points on any other rotating object.
A point of magnetic focus, especially each of the two opposing such points of a magnet (designated north and south).
(geometry) A fixed point relative to other points or lines.
(electricity) A contact on an electrical device (such as a battery) at which electric current enters or leaves.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The firmament; the sky.
Either of the states that characterize a bipolar disorder.

verbs.description: pole (third-person singular simple present poles, present participle poling, simple past and past participle poled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To induce piezoelectricity in (a substance) by aligning the dipoles.
